destination.label: Pointe-a-Pitre
destination.title: An island of contrasts between land and sea

content.intro:
Caribbean sun, white sandy beaches, turquoise sea and more…welcome to the tropical islands of Guadeloupe, a French overseas region located around 7,000km from mainland France.

Guadeloupe, a narrow territory that is part of the Lesser Antilles in the Caribbean Sea, comprises several islands with vastly different, unspoiled landscapes, all united under the French flag. The largest, posed like a butterfly in the middle of the water, is called 'Karukera' in Amerindian. Its mountainous topography, flourishing nature, and the diversity of its beaches make it the most spectacular of the archipelago's islands. It has two regions: Grande-Terre and Basse-Terre.

Grande Terre, the right wing of the butterfly, is flat and arid, and is the most popular tourist area with the most beautiful beaches. The shores of golden sand are lined with coconut trees and lapped by crystal-clear water. It is a paradise for water sports enthusiasts. Most hotels are located on its coast, notably in Le Gosier, Sainte-Anne, Saint-François, and along to the Pointe des Châteaux. Not far away, Pointe-à-Pitre forms the head of this beautiful butterfly, while Basse-Terre, mountainous and green, is the left wing. This region is a veritable lush Garden of Eden where the La Soufrière volcano takes centre stage. A heavenly spot for divers, Basse-Terre is also much-loved by hikers for Guadeloupe National Park: a tropical forest dotted with waterfalls, vertical drops, trails lined with ancient trees, and black sand beaches.

A few nautical miles away are the southern islands, with poetic names like Marie-Galante, Petite-Terre, La Désirade, and Les Saintes evoking enchanting lagoons, protected wildlife, and unspoiled nature. The Petite-Terre Reserve is an iguana paradise. Marie-Galante, known for its beaches and rum, offers a journey back in time, far from the more popular tourist haunts. La Désirade, often compared to the island of Robinson Crusoe, inspires calm with its heavenly beaches and deserted landscapes. Les Saintes offers an unparalleled spectacle, featuring one of the most beautiful bays in the world.

You will be amazed by so much beauty and diversity, with something to suit everyone: from ideal spots for sitting back and relaxing, to sports and exploring. With temperatures of 27°C and waters at 25°C all year round, a trip to Guadeloupe promises to be an absolute joy. So what are you waiting for?

content.title: Karacoli, the temple of chill

introduction.small: On the beach of Grande Anse in Deshaies, Karacoli brings a new lease of life to the concept of a beach club, where relaxation is the key.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Karacoli, the temple of chill

paragraphs.text:
Karacoli's main selling point is its unique, postcard setting. But this beach bar on Grande Anse beach stands out from other ‘beach clubs' by really revisiting the idea of chill. Families, couples and groups of friends can meet here for a day, right by the water, feet in the sand. Once you have comfortably settled in a hammock, a deckchair or sheltered from the bright sun in a carbet Amarindian wooden beach hut that you can hire out for yourself, share some tapas and cocktails (with or without alcohol) that you can create yourself.

The spa completes this offer of relaxation with a sauna, à la carte massages (30 to 50 minutes), foot reflexology and treatments (exfoliation, mud wrap). This is an unmissable spot to recharge your batteries and end a perfect day watching an unforgettable sunset over the ocean.

Karacoli Beach & Spa
Plage de Grande Anse
97126 Deshaies

+590 (0)6 90 52 78 60

https://karacoli.com

Menu: drinks from 7 EUR

content.title: Mahina, snacking by the water's edge

introduction.small: In the north of Basse-Terre, this restaurant and tapas bar enjoys an exceptional location and offers varied cuisine using local ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mahina, snacking by the water's edge

paragraphs.text:
Amid the small and sheltered Deshaies community, there is a charming restaurant settled right across the bay. Well-known by regulars, Mahina offers a gorgeous panorama over the surrounding nature. The establishment boasts a relaxing atmosphere, whether for lunch or a simple late-afternoon snack. To fully enjoy the experience, make sure to book a table to guarantee you will have access to a splendid view over the sailing boats moored in the bay.
The menu is quite extensive: from unmissable fresh fish to grilled meat, copious tapas platters, pasta and pizza. The variety of dishes is enough to make you giddy (with delight)! As it should be, local specialities include ti'-punch (that you make up yourself by adding sugar and lime) and the Planter's punch, considered to be one of the best in the region. Enjoy in moderation, as you watch the sun vanishing below the horizon.

Mahina
139 boulevard des poissonniers
97126 Deshaies

+33 (0)5 90 88 95 38

https://www.facebook.com/deshaies.lemahina

Menu: from 19 EUR

content.title: In the footsteps of slavery in Guadeloupe

introduction.small: On 27 May 1848, Governor Layrle proclaimed the abolition of slavery in Guadeloupe. Explore the sites that celebrate this key moment in the island's history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the footsteps of slavery in Guadeloupe

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 1994 in Benin, the Slave Route Project has worked to put together an inventory of places of history and memory related to the slave trade and slavery. Historians, researchers and heritage experts involved in these questions gathered in Guadeloupe to create the first tour dedicated to the victims of slavery to have received recognition from and the label of UNESCO.

Initiated by the international organisation, the project aims to contribute to a better understanding of the causes and challenges of slavery in the world, to highlight global transformations, to foster intercultural and identity dialogue within the country and, finally, to fight against ignorance and forgetfulness. From Fort Louis Delgrès to the Canal des Rotours or Roussel-Trianon, 18 unique sites will plunge you into the heart of the past.

The Slave Route Project

www.lesilesdeguadeloupe.com/tourism/en-fr/tours/circuitpatrimoniallaroutedelesclave-6jours5nuits

content.title: A wild getaway at the Pointe des Châteaux

introduction.small: Recognised by the French Ministry of Ecology and Sustainable Development for its archaeological wealth and endemic species, the site of the Pointe des Châteaux is worth the detour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A wild getaway at the Pointe des Châteaux

paragraphs.text:
To the east of Guadeloupe, a long peninsula resists the wind and the waves that erode the rock and sweep aside the sand. Since 1999, the "great national site" operation, actively supported by the town of Saint François, has been fighting to preserve the Pointe des Châteaux by creating hiking trails and proper signposts while protecting beaches and salt mines.
Every year, 500,000 visitors climb up to the Morne Pavillon panoramic viewpoint that leads to a 32-feet high cross weighing nine tonnes, erected in honour of the diocese centenary. From the summit, you can see La Désirade, a small island inhabited by many Bretons, and right next to it the Petite Terre nature reserve. Also within sight is Marie-Galante, an island that is home to a hundred mills. And on clear days, you may see Basse-Terre and the Les Saintes archipelago. Beautiful hiking guaranteed!

https://www.pointe-des-chateaux.com

content.title: Chez Tatie Clotilde: family-style Caribbean cooking

introduction.small: Far from the tourist scene, Chez Tatie Clotilde specialises in authentic Guadeloupean cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Tatie Clotilde: family-style Caribbean cooking

paragraphs.text:
A mere five minutes from the beach, in a small alley in St. Anne, wafts of delicious aromas fill the late morning air from the Chez Tatie Clotilde kitchen. In this tiny picturesque restaurant – filled with eight oilcloth-covered tables, and just five minutes from the beach – its vivacious owner Clotilde serves family-style Creole home cooking. Her Guadeloupean dishes (red snapper broth, chicken colombo, boudin sausages, and cod fritters) are staples of Caribbean culinary tradition, served to you in a relaxed and friendly no-frills setting. The food - and the low prices - attract crowds of regulars, so it is it is best to book in the morning if you want to get a table for lunch. The only downside: Aunt Clotilde is an early riser and closes at night.

Chez Tatie Clotilde
34 rue Dandin
97180 Sainte-Anne

+590 (0)5 90 88 26 59

https://www.facebook.com/Restaurant-Chez-Tatie-Clotilde-109205090758367/

Menu: around 17 EUR

content.title: A room in the shade of flowering banana trees

introduction.small: Central location, quiet, reasonable prices: Hotel Les Bananiers is a gem of comfort and simplicity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A room in the shade of flowering banana trees

paragraphs.text:
A 15-minute walk from the beach and the village of Gosier, the Hotel Les Bananiers is a welcome alternative to the tourist bustle, but still close enough that you can take full advantage of its attractions. It consists of several Creole buildings around a pool in a tropical garden of banana trees. The four bedrooms and four studios in this simple and very Caribbean setting are pleasant and cosy.

The day starts with a delicious complimentary breakfast of fresh fruit, served on a pretty terrace surrounded by lush vegetation. The studios have kitchenettes and private terraces overlooking the pool. The proportions are prefect, and Florence and Bernard, the two owners, are founts of knowledge about what to see and do on the island, including how to get off the beaten track…

Hôtel Les Bananiers
Rue des Phares et Balises
Perinet
97190 Le Gosier

+590 (0)5 90 84 10 91

https://www.facebook.com/bananiers

Rooms: from 91 EUR

content.title: Ahoy there, matey!

introduction.small: La Rhumerie du Pirate is an institution in Saint-François. Its Creole dishes, rums, and amusing decor seduce Guadeloupeans as much as tourists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ahoy there, matey!

paragraphs.text:
Pull out your telescope and plot your course for Pointe des Châteaux and this colourful restaurant with its Pirates of the Caribbean atmosphere, hosted by the restaurant's very own Captain Jack Sparrow! This large wooden Creole hut has a beach-wrecked charm, as though it had somehow washed up here on its own. Inside or outside? If you get the chance then head to the huge terrace, where you will enjoy a refreshing sea breeze and panoramic views of the ocean, Marie-Galante, Les Saintes, and Petite-Terre, whose lighthouse is sometimes visible on a clear day.

Then it is time to sit down to dinner! The menu features delicious Caribbean cuisine and traditional dishes prepared by the chef, Miguel, including tuna steak, chatrou (octopus) or crayfish fricassee, and lobster. With six reasonably priced Creole set menus to choose from, you can try all of the local specialities. For dessert, the coconut flan is a great success, the coconut sorbet is exceptional and the tiramisu with old rum, sensational. For a table with a sea view, remember to book in advance.

La Rhumerie du Pirate
Route de la Pointe des Châteaux
97118 Saint-François

+590 (0)5 90 83 25 94

https://larhumeriedupirate.fr/

Menu: around 31 EUR

content.title: Coco Kafé: an open kitchen between land and sea

introduction.small: A chic and contemporary restaurant in the heart of the Le Gosier Marina offering unique cuisine to order. Gastropub for some; for others, a bistro.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Coco Kafé: an open kitchen between land and sea

paragraphs.text:
The Coco Kafé looks great by the boats. It seems like a docked ship, with its boat-deck terrace and parasol sails. Do you feel like going for a sail and watching the boats? Head along the boardwalk to grab a table at the water's edge.

Nature is outside, inside, and everywhere, with Zen decoration of exotic plants, rocks, and water in a 100% wooden structure. The space is warm and exudes modernity, complete with an open kitchen.

This is the home of chef Jean-Claude Valvason, who writes up his slate based on what he's found at the market and from the fishmongers. Daily specials are added to a menu founded on traditional cuisine and specialties of Guadeloupe. Grilled sirloin steak, sea bream or the Coco Kafé's signature dish, the famous Coco Maïpo chicken, served on a griddle, are a delight. An all-round treat, especially at night when all the candles are lit, creating a magical atmosphere.

Coco Kafé
Place Créole La Marina
97190 Le Gosier

+590 (0)5 90 93 63 02

https://www.facebook.com/Coco-Kaf%C3%A9-1463044037309479/

Menu: around 32 EUR

content.title: Grande-Terre: white sand and coconut palms

introduction.small: Grande-Terre is celebrated for its beautiful beaches and stunning turquoise lagoons such as La Caravelle, Raisins Clairs, and the Salines.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grande-Terre: white sand and coconut palms

paragraphs.text:
A limestone island with fairly flat terrain, Grand-Terre has an irresistible asset: its long white sandy beaches with coconut palms and crystal-clear water. More touristy than its sister, it is home to most of the hotels, often located right on the seafront, such as on La Caravelle Beach, which is probably the most famous of all.

Located in the small town of Sainte-Anne, it offers a postcard landscape with its pristine sand, palm trees, and shallow-water paradise for swimmers. Equally idyllic, the long beach of Raisins Clairs in Saint-François, is sought after for its shady trees. Its poetic name comes from the seagrape trees (whose fruits look like regular grapes) bordering the beach.

Farther on, at the Pointe des Chateaux, relax on Salines Beach, facing La Désirade, or that of Anse at la Gourde, close to the Anse du Mancenillier. In Le Gosier, discover Gosier Island Beach or that of Petit-Havre, which are quiet and sublime, and on the west coast, Anse du Souffleur is a must.

Saint-François Tourism Office
Avenue de l'Europe
97118 Saint-François

+590 (0)5 90 68 66 81

https://www.facebook.com/Office-de-Tourisme-de-Saint-François-334475829942621/

content.title: Ô Z'Épices: healthy cooking from garden to plate

introduction.small: It's love at first bite for the restaurant Ô Z'épices and its talented chef, who offers seasonal organic cuisine with medicinal virtues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ô Z'Épices: healthy cooking from garden to plate

paragraphs.text:
In Bouillante, above the sea, 40 privileged diners have the chance each day to taste the recipes of Jimmy Bibrac. This charismatic chef brings diners food like no other, with produce coming from within just a 50m radius. How is this possible? Simply by growing vegetables in a large on-site organic garden. There are fruits and vegetables, but also aromatic and medicinal plants like lemongrass, basil, sage, and local redcurrants.

For fish, the fishermen bring their catch of the day. The same goes for meat and poultry. Jimmy Bibrac believes that diet and health are intimately linked and the power of plants is beyond doubt. He works them in all forms, from dishes to desserts and even herbal teas, offered after a meal and chosen according to what you have eaten.

There is no fixed menu, only the slate with daily specials for starters, main courses and desserts, all prepared by the chef. These might include a pair of rock lobsters, fins of ray in turmeric, and, finally, rosemary custard. A tasty and beneficial dining experience.

Ô Z'Épices
Falaise
97125 Bouillante

+590 (0)5 90 38 87 61

https://www.ozepices.net

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: Seafood delights on La Désirade!

introduction.small: At Lagranlag, fish is cooked and honoured in all its forms: grilled, stewed, in a broth… however you like it!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Seafood delights on La Désirade!

paragraphs.text:
It takes just 45 minutes to reach this much 'desired' island, thus appropriately named by Columbus' crew. If you go there, make sure to try the food prepared by Chantal at Lagranlag in Beauséjour, between the pier and 'Fifi' Beach. It is an unpretentious local shed, but serves excellent cuisine prepared with fresh, local ingredients.

The fish menu displays French and Creole dishes with gourmet flavours. Specialties not to be missed include such creations as conch fricassee or lobster with a renowned gratin of vegetables grown on La Désirade.

Remember to order the house dessert, too: it is called Lagranlagaise, and inspired by the local specialty: coated ice syrup with cashew fruit, which only the islanders know the secret to. You can also taste another local specialty - ti'-punch with local olives. There is a whole host of Désiradien flavours to discover here!

Lagranlag
Beauséjour
97127 La Désirade

+590 (0)5 90 20 01 00

https://www.facebook.com/restaurantlagranlag/

Menu: around 18 EUR

content.title: Discover the rainforest

introduction.small: Whether walking or hiking, the Guadeloupian forest is a source of wonder. There are more than 300km of marked trails, for total immersion in this exceptional natural environment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the rainforest

paragraphs.text:
Whether you enjoy a gentle stroll or are an avid hiker, discovering the Guadeloupe National Park rainforest is a must.

Whatever your level, whether you are up for a 50-minute journey to observe the biodiversity of the site and learn about the flora and fauna, or a five or six-day trek, there is something for everyone. The best known is the GR G1 trail, also known as the 'Trace des Alizés', which runs the entire length of Basse-Terre, along ridges that connect Vieux-Fort to Sainte-Rose. You can walk it in about a week. Along the way there are free shelters accessible to walkers. This is an adventure reserved for experienced, well-trained hikers with a solid knowledge of the tropics.

As a precaution, it is advisable to contact a tour guide or local association before embarking on this trek, which takes you through amazing flora and a majestic rainforest.

Parc national de la Guadeloupe
Montéran
97120 Saint Claude

+590 (0)5 90 41 55 55

www.guadeloupe-parcnational.fr

content.title: Fish and shellfish on Marie-Galante

introduction.small: La Playa is ranked among the best restaurants in the Caribbean. Enjoy the tasty seafood-inspired cuisine in a holiday atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fish and shellfish on Marie-Galante

paragraphs.text:
If you go to Marie-Galante, stop at La Playa, as the chef Jerome Hagège will treat you like royalty. In Capesterre on the coast road, opposite Feuillère Beach - one of the prettiest on the island - its white-and-blue facade will make you want to stop.

Seaside decor in white wood, punctuated by touches of turquoise, striped nautical blinds, and hanging fishnets makes this a choice setting for a cuisine that heavily emphasises fish and shellfish from the island.

From coconut crab to fish carpaccio and crayfish, there are plenty of colourful Creole dishes to enjoy, but the house specialty is lobster straight from the Marie-Galante lagoon. Prepared to order, you can choose your own lobster from those on offer, which is then grilled to perfection. A treat full of unforgettable flavour that you need to try, but make sure to book in advance.

La Playa
Route du Littoral
Lieu-dit Bernard
97140 Capesterre
Marie-Galante

+590 (0)5 90 93 66 10

https://www.facebook.com/laplayamariegalante/

Menu: around 37 EUR

content.title: Luxurious rooms facing the turquoise bay of Saint-François

introduction.small: Between sea and countryside, the Hotel La Cocoteraie is located on the most beautiful lagoon in Guadeloupe, near the international golf course. Its 50 rooms are all suites!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Luxurious rooms facing the turquoise bay of Saint-François

paragraphs.text:
The atmosphere in this four-star seafront hotel is chic and elegant and you will feel in the holiday spirit as soon as you arrive. The hotel's reception, which feels like a colonial mansion with light colours and Caribbean-inspired architecture, is an invitation to relaxation and wellness.

Everything inspires serenity, from the pontoons and buildings in white wood or pastel to the chalk-coloured roofs, while the 50 suites with an area of 50 to 75 sqm provide real tranquillity for two to four people.

All in white tones with some exotic touches, they consist of a bedroom, a living room, and a private terrace with views of the sea, garden, or marina.

After your night in the tropics, breakfast is served at La Varangue or the Indigo bar, overlooking the magnificent 1,000-sqm pool with its beautiful porcelains, immersed in azure blue water, the colour of the sky and the sea. Indulge a bit, and allow yourself to drift off into a Caribbean slumber…

Hotel La Cocoteraie by Popinns
Avenue de l'Europe
97118 Saint-François

+590 (0)5 90 88 79 81

https://cocoteraie.popinns.com/index.php?lg=en

Rooms: from 135 EUR

content.title: Rickshaw taxi in Pointe-à-Pitre

introduction.small: Enjoy a guided tour of Pointe-à-Pitre by rickshaw taxi. Take in all the charms of the city in this eco-friendly vehicle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rickshaw taxi in Pointe-à-Pitre

paragraphs.text:
Climb aboard this three-wheeled cart, pulled by a cheerful cyclist ready to take you on a city discovery, and succumb to the subtle charms of this city of art and history.

Ride through its unusual streets to visit markets, museums, the Basilica of St. Peter and St. Paul. It is best to visit the city in the early morning to enjoy its lively and colourful markets, including the Saint-Antoine Market, also known as the 'spice market', run mainly by 'doudous' in their ample dresses and madras headscarves selling spices and homemade products, such as fritters and macerated rums. In the main street of Saint-John Perse, you can visit the house where the eponymous diplomat, poet, and Nobel Prize-winner for literature - whose real name was Alexis Léger (1887-1975) - grew up. Do some shopping on Frébault street and admire the charming wooden houses, such as the Forier House, a fine example of colonial architecture. During this trip, your driver will punctuate their stops with anecdotes, memories, and historical information. Do not miss the Memorial ACTe, a new centre dedicated to the memory of slavery.

After this eco-friendly tour, do not forget to thank your passionate cyclist…

Rickshaw Taxis
Place du marché aux Épices
97110 Pointe-à-Pitre

+590 (0)6 90 61 47 37

https://www.facebook.com/Poussepoussetaxi

content.title: Les Suggestions d'Alen Coliné: exclusive market cuisine

introduction.small: In Baie-Mahault, chef Alain Coliné develops an ever-evolving Creole cuisine, where seafood and local vegetables are given pride of place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Suggestions d'Alen Coliné: exclusive market cuisine

paragraphs.text:
You will not regret your trip after tasting the proposed menu. Here, the cuisine takes on all its meaning, enhancing the flavours. Every day, depending on the local fishermen's catch of the day, market produce, and the season, the chef prepares his menu around fresh new flavours that are constantly updated.

Coliné takes a creative approach to Creole cuisine, combining unusual ingredients that always find a happy harmony. A fish and a meat choice are offered daily; for example, sea bream fillet with pineapple or lamb chops with ginger, lima beans and melon, followed by a supreme de gratin of green bananas - all are simply divine.

To end on a sweet note, give in to the temptation of a sweet potato fondant. The chef shares his passion for Guadeloupe produce through his original recipes, while the setting offers a beautiful view of the sea.

Les Suggestions d'Alen Coliné
Rue Emmanuel Condo
97122 Baie-Mahault

+590 (0)5 90 26 14 09 / +590 (0)6 90 55 22 34

https://www.lessuggestionsdalencoline.fr/

Menu: around 29 EUR

content.title: Swimming under a waterfall

introduction.small: Take advantage of the remarkable hikes and swimming in Basse-Terre National Park with its serial cascades, huge waterfalls, bubbling pools, and mysterious lakes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Swimming under a waterfall

paragraphs.text:
Forget the ocean beaches and immerse yourself in the most beautiful freshwaters of Guadeloupe the Carbet, Moreau, and Galion Falls, Bras du Fort waterfall, the Saut de la Lézarde, and Acomat... These enchanting names offer moments of sheer delight in the heart of the rainforest.

There are also hiking trails that are marked and classified by level, some accessible to all, others more demanding and deserving of preparation or an experienced guide. For long walks, it is best to go in the morning, especially for Moreau Falls, which is two-and-a-half hours from the starting point, or a five-hour round trip.

The three Carbet waterfalls are a must, with one being no less than 115m high. Equally charming with clear transparent water is the waterfall of the Saut Lézarde, with its 12m drop that flows into a 50m pool. It is a veritable fountain of youth!

content.title: Listen to the song of the whales

introduction.small: From December to May, during mating and calving season, you can watch and listen to the humpback whales that come to give birth in the Caribbean's warm, calm waters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Listen to the song of the whales

paragraphs.text:
Going out to meet humpback whales and their young calves is possible by embarking on a research boat with the nature guides from the Shelltone Whale Project. If you are lucky, you can get close to these huge marine animals.

These 12-16m-long giants weigh 25-45 tonnes, and are easily recognisable by their black backs and humps in front of the dorsal fin. Present in several locations on the island, including Porte d'Enfer, Pointe des Chateaux, and Great Vigie, they arrive in December, at the heart of mating season, and leave in May for the cold waters of the north Atlantic when the calves reach two to three months. They head back north, to New England, to look for krill, a mix primarily of small shrimp and herring, and then they return the following year to give birth and mate again, which allows scientists to identify them and to better understand their habits.

You may be surprised by the courtship ritual, where the males, who are very demonstrative, jump and 'stand' vertically, while 'singing' a very strange song...

Shelltone Whale Project is a general interest association carrying out scientific research on cetaceans. They offer visitors a considerate, conscious approach to experiencing an incredible moment with humpback whales, sperm whales, dolphins, pilot whales, and false killer whales.

Shelltone Whale Project
Port de Baille Argent
97116 Pointe-Noire

https://www.shelltonewhaleproject.org/en/eco-whale-watching/

content.title: Marie-Galante: the charm of yesteryear

introduction.small: The largest of the southern islands, celebrated by poets and adored by the Guadeloupeans for its authenticity, its beauty, its countryside, its mills, its rum, and its cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marie-Galante: the charm of yesteryear

paragraphs.text:
Thirty kilometres southeast of Guadeloupe and 45 minutes by boat from Pointe-à-Pitre, Marie-Galante, nicknamed the 'Great Pancake' because of its size, shape, and low relief, is distinguished by its picturesque agricultural charm. Here time seems suspended, and life is punctuated by the business of sugar cane, always cut by hand and transported on ox carts to one of the distilleries of the island: Bellevue, Bielle, or Poisson-Père Labat. Hiking is great in the green countryside, where you can discover the many mills, vestiges of a bygone era.

Steeped in tradition and true hospitality, Marie-Galante is concentrated around three villages. Grand-Bourg, the largest town with its many shops, offers gorgeous white sandy beaches, with a lagoon protected by a coral reef. In Capesterre, take a cart ride along the 'paths of the cane' or laze upon its large white sand beaches lined with coconut trees.

Finally, St. Louis, further west, with its old fort, offers wild landscapes and breathtaking views, such as the one from Guele Grand-Gouffre.

Marie-Galante Tourism Office
Rue Pierre Leroy
97112 Grand-Bourg
Marie-Galante

+590 (0)5 90 97 56 51

https://www.ot-mariegalante.com/en

content.title: Paddle boarding and exploration at Moule Beach

introduction.small: How about a paddle boarding trip around Moule Beach? Here's another way to discover the lagoon, sheltered from the breeze.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Paddle boarding and exploration at Moule Beach

paragraphs.text:
A short tour around the bay, a long sweep around the lagoon, or an unforgettable trip through the mangroves: stand-up paddleboards allow you to discover places that are inaccessible on foot, while also giving you a sense of freedom. It is quite simple; you just stand on your board and paddle, gliding wherever you like. This is a sport open to all and one that can be mastered quite quickly. Based at Le Moule Beach, the stand-up paddle boarding school offers two-hour tours, accompanied by a guide, through the mangroves and the meanderings of this huge rainforest.

For the more athletic, eager for thrills, try your hand at 'paddle surfing' or 'downwind paddle boarding', supervised by experienced riders who will teach you the secrets of endless surf on the long swells of the Atlantic. Enjoy a truly athletic adventure!

Supin Gwada
Port de Pêche
97160 Le Moule

+590 (0)6 90 00 66 13

supingwada.com

content.title: Caribbean specialties in the world's most beautiful bay

introduction.small: Ti Kaz 'La, a real treat in a magnificent setting… What more can we say?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Caribbean specialties in the world's most beautiful bay

paragraphs.text:
With your feet in the water facing the lagoon of Terre-de-Haut, it is impossible to imagine a better location on Les Saintes. And that's not all, because the food is divine, the service friendly, and the décor simple and tasteful. As for the view it is quite simply stunning.

In high season it is best to book to taste the chef's specialties, which unsurprisingly are all focused around local fish and shellfish, combining French and Saintoise cuisine with largely local produce grown on the island and fish caught off Les Saintes. Just a glance of the menu will take you on a journey of flavours, with Caribbean tuiles de tapas, lobster ravioli with fermented vegetable juices, swordfish carpaccio with Roquefort and grilled chorizo, roasted lobster à l'antillaise, and the chef's specialty: choucroute de la mer, a seafood stew.

These inventive dishes will keep you smiling all the way through to the end of your dessert. If you go to Les Saintes, do not resist this wonderful culinary stopover.

Ti Kaz' La
10, rue Benoît Cassin
97137 Terre-de-Haut

+590 (0)5 90 99 57 63

https://www.tikazla.com/en/

Menu: around 41 EUR

content.title: Bwa Chik, a golfer's hideaway

introduction.small: Located across from the international golf course in Saint-François, close to the lagoon, Bwa Chik Hotel & Golf focuses on nature in an eco-chic spirit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bwa Chik, a golfer's hideaway

paragraphs.text:
This three-star hotel enjoys an excellent location for sports and, more importantly, for golfers. It is right across from the completely renovated 18-hole golf course designed by the famous Robert Trent Jones Sr. in 1978. It is a well-known course with wide fairways, numerous bunkers, and giant coconut trees.

To maintain this natural atmosphere, the hotel has invested in natural colours and raw materials, like driftwood. This sweet harmony continues in the 54 rooms, decorated with charm and simplicity in chocolate and ivory tones. Continuing the theme, the headboards and furniture are made of raw wood, while the lamps and bed covers are all in white.

Outside, the curving pool is perfect for the late afternoon. Better yet, find happiness on the beach of Saint-François, with its South Seas blue waters, a five-minute walk away. The choice is yours whether to swim, jet ski, sail, or snorkel.

Bwa Chik Hôtel & Golf
Avenue de l'Europe
97118 Saint-François

+590 (0)5 90 88 60 60

https://bwachik.com/?lang=en

Rooms: from 104 EUR

content.title: Adventures on a desert island

introduction.small: Explore Petite-Terre, a paradise consisting of two uninhabited islets and home to over 10,000 iguanas, agoutis, and migratory birds that breed there.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Adventures on a desert island

paragraphs.text:
This piece of wild land, located 11 kilometres from the Saint-François Marina has been a nature reserve since 1998 and is an exceptional place, both for its wildlife and for its seabed.

The two islands, Terre-de-Bas and Terre-de-Haut, are separated by a narrow channel, forming a lagoon bursting with colourful fish, rays, turtles, lemon sharks, and barracudas that you can admire by equipping yourself with a mask and snorkel. You can only dock on Terre-de-Bas, the land of the Lesser Antillean Iguana, a protected species. You will come across dozens of both young and adult iguanas, which can grow up to 1.6m and weigh three kilograms. Terre-de-Haut, however, is not accessible, as it is a protected nature reserve for green turtles, which lay their eggs there. Jet skis are forbidden around Petite-Terre and the ONF (National Forests Office) and the Coastal Conservancy limit the number of visitors to Terre-de Bas to 200 per day.

Finally, when leaving you may be lucky enough to see some dolphins who have chosen to make the outskirts of Petite-Terre their home. Truly a day of dreams!

https://www.petite-terre.com/

content.title: Basse-Terre: volcanic black and ochre sand beaches

introduction.small: The left wing of the butterfly, Basse-Terre, between sea and mountains, is lush with vegetation. It is a paradise for hikers and nature lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Basse-Terre: volcanic black and ochre sand beaches

paragraphs.text:
This volcanic island, which is partly classified as a reserve, is home to the Guadeloupe National Park. Its rainforest, volcano, mountains, waterfalls, and wild shores are the work of capricious and radiant nature, as evidenced by its black, brown, or tan sand beaches, with the different colours evidence of the island's volcanic activity.

The most famous of all is Grande Anse Trois-Rivières, with its long shore laid out at the foot of the verdant mountain and one of the best spots to watch the sunset. The same tones can be seen at Banana Beach, with its black sand and coconut trees, and at Anse à la Barque, while the sand is grey on Roseau Beach, in Sainte-Marie. Its calm and peaceful waters attract families, who find the place ideal for young children.

The west coast, facing the Caribbean Sea, offers lighter shades, like those on Malendure Beach in the village of Bouillante. Although they are all different, these beaches share some common features, including a water temperature above 25ºC, so swimming is always a pleasure.

Trois-Rivières Tourism Office
Le Bourg
3 rue Gerville Réache
97114 Trois-Rivières

+590 (0)5 90 92 77 01

https://www.lesilesdeguadeloupe.com/tourism/en-fr/the-islands/basse-terre

content.title: At the heart of the Cousteau reserve

introduction.small: This most famous of Guadeloupe's diving spots is a 400-hectare nature reserve and an underwater Garden of Eden. A fascinating world to discover either under the water or on it.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At the heart of the Cousteau reserve

paragraphs.text:
Off Malendure beach on the west coast of Basse-Terre, the Pigeon Islands are a paradise for divers. There are no fewer than 16 sites, including three shipwrecks located ten minutes from the beach: the Franjack at 24m (easy dive), the Gustavia at 40m (experienced divers only) and the Augustin Fresnel II at 29m (experienced divers only). Its protected seabed contains a dizzying array of species, such as amazing sea sponges, brain coral, turtles, and schools of colourful damsel and clown fish.

In the Coral Garden, another surprise awaits divers. Lying ten metres below the water is the bronze bust of Commander Jacques Cousteau, a homage to the famous commander of the Calypso and his film, The Silent World, shot partly on this site. There is not only scuba diving and snorkelling, as other opportunities are available to you when visiting this underwater park. Embark on a glass bottom boat or even more original, go for an night dive to explore a completely different, and even more magical side to the underwater world by torchlight. This is an unforgettable and completely safe excursion, where you will be accompanied by a team of professional divers.

https://www.reserve-cousteau.com

content.title: A thermal treatment in curative waters

introduction.small: Balneotherapy and bathing in 33°C spring waters… the virtues of the Ravine Chaude Spa complex are well known to all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A thermal treatment in curative waters

paragraphs.text:
Originally built in the 1960s, this Spa underwent a complete renovation just a few years ago. Its outstanding location in Basse-Terre, 110m above sea level and built against the mountain's lush vegetation, makes it an idyllic space both for its environment and the quality of its care.

Its therapeutic waters flow at a temperature of 33°C from the springs of the Lézarde heights, close to the volcano, leading directly into the pool, showers, and other facilities. The thermal mineral waters are rich in iron and calcium, and a range of other minerals that are beneficial for rheumatism and skin diseases. With its pool, whirlpool, and balneotherapy, this Spa complex and its modern facilities ensure ultimate wellness.

Whether you opt for a rejuvenating treatment or a therapeutic relaxation session, these waters are sure to invigorate your body and mind, and boost your energy. There are several packages available for treatments and day passes.

Ravine Chaude René Toribio Thermal Baths Spa Complex
Chemin de Ravine Chaude
97129 Lamentin

+590 (0)5 90 57 16 70

https://ravinechaude.business.site/

content.title: Caprice des Îles: Caribbean cuisine in Basse-Terre

introduction.small: A well-known establishment for foodies and lovers of good Creole cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Caprice des Îles: Caribbean cuisine in Basse-Terre

paragraphs.text:
The Caprice des Îles is located in Baillif, off the Pointe de la Madeleine, a perfect stop for lunch or dinner if you are anywhere around Guadeloupe National Park. Upon arrival, you will find a warm and friendly atmosphere with welcoming staff, which is always an excellent start.

You can choose between the Caribbean terrace with a trade-winds sea breeze, or inside with its vividly coloured Creole decor. If you have the opportunity, head for the tranquillity of the terrace and its spectacular views. The dining room, albeit very pleasant, is slightly noisier.

Now for a tasting and a discovery of Caribbean cuisine centred around lovingly cooked fish specialties, chatrou (octopus), grilled lobster, yam croquettes, or more original proposals such as vegetable fritters, rack of lamb with Creole sauce, and fresh fish blaff hot pot. The dishes are executed with precision and originality, and taste divine. Certainly a meal to remember!

Caprice des Îles
Avenue du Père-Labat
97123 Baillif

+590 (0)5 90 81 74 97

https://www.capricedesiles.com

Menu: around 29 EUR

content.title: Climbing to the top of the ‘Old Lady'

introduction.small: The burning heart of Guadeloupe, La Soufrière offers a breath-taking view of the Lesser Antilles from its 1,467m summit; a magical reward for intrepid hikers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climbing to the top of the ‘Old Lady'

paragraphs.text:
The active volcano La Soufrière, in the south of Basse-Terre, produces Peléan eruptions that spew viscous lava; its last violent eruption dates back to 1976-1977. Since then, La Soufrière has been constantly monitored, so rest assured you will be closely watched over for the three hours it takes for ascent and descent. You can organise this hike on your own or with an experienced guide who will show you all the depths and chasms of the 'Old Lady'.

Depending on the weather, try to opt for a morning walk to get to the top under a cloudless sky. If you leave from the Bains Jaunes carpark, you should reach the top in an hour and a half. On a clear day the view over Les Saintes, Marie-Galante, and Dominica is beautiful. Enjoy this interlude before the rocky path of the Chemin des Dames, no less than 300m up.

To really test your commitment, the last 50 metres of the climb are the steepest. Your reward at the top is the spectacular 360° view of Guadeloupe and its surrounding islets. It is just as beautiful on a cloudy day, when the landscape appears lunar and spooky.

La Soufrière
97120 Saint-Claude

https://www.la-soufriere.com

content.title: Creole ambiance for family holidays

introduction.small: Amid palm trees, hibiscus, and bougainvillea, the Creole Beach Hotel & Spa opts for modernity and relaxation in a friendly atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Creole ambiance for family holidays

paragraphs.text:
With a tropical-garden setting right on the beach, the location of the Creole Beach Hotel in Pointe de la Verdure, one kilometre from Le Gosier, is a delight. This is a heavenly place for a holiday with family or friends, where everything is in place to help you slow down. You can take advantage of numerous water sports, the spa, the kids club, and two restaurants.

The decor in the main building has a fairly contemporary style, with exterior wood dressed in white, grey, or natural hues. Similarly, the 211 spacious rooms surrounded by luscious vegetation have direct access to the beach, and are decorated with bright tones and wooden furniture. Each morning, you are just a few steps from a plunge into 25°C waters, followed by some kayaking or windsurfing. After a well-deserved break in a deckchair on the white sand, enjoy lunch at La Route des Épices, around the large pool.

If you need a wellness break, head to the spa for the best treatments, featuring Payot products. For dinner, sample the lobster and Creole dishes at Le Zawag, followed by a trip to the La Rhumerie bar and its sublime menu of aged rums.

La Créole Beach Hotel & Spa
Pointe de la Verdure

+590 (0)5 90 90 46 46

https://www.creolebeach.com/en/

Rooms: from 156 EUR

content.title: One night – or maybe more – on La Caravelle beach

introduction.small: Club Med has a dream location on La Caravelle beach, one of the most beautiful on the island, where you will find an endless choice of water sports.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: One night – or maybe more – on La Caravelle beach

paragraphs.text:
On the southern coast of Grande-Terre, about 20 kilometres from Pointe-à-Pitre, the village of Sainte-Anne stands out for its white sandy beaches, crystal-clear waters, and turquoise lagoon. Club Med really hit the mark when setting up its resort on the beach at La Caravelle. Coconut trees, fine sand, and a 25°C sea for swimming whenever the mood strikes. Stay of a night or a week, and take advantage of the many sports and other festivities.

Between the pool, tennis, windsurfing, and kayaking, it will be hard to choose. And while the flying trapeze might make you a little dizzy, why not try a somersault between swims?

When it comes to rooms, opt for the Marie-Galante building for its incredible views, looking out over the Caribbean. You can also choose between the 30 or 60-sqm simple rooms, or the 50 or 70-sqm suites! For light meals, the Hibiscus restaurant and its sumptuous buffets are perfect, or, for a more intimate experience, try the Biguine. Everything you need for a memorable stay is here.

Club Med La Caravelle

content.title: Auberge de la Vieille Tour: a sure thing

introduction.small: On the south coast of Grande-Terre, between sea and countryside, this luxury hotel, built around an 18th-century windmill, exudes charm and privacy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Auberge de la Vieille Tour: a sure thing

paragraphs.text:
A landmark, the Auberge de la Vielle Tour is one of the most famous hotels in Guadeloupe. Its location near Pointe-à-Pitre, at the entry of Le Gosier, is ideal for visits to the surrounding islands.

Built against the old mill, the Creole-style building lies in a tropical three-hectare garden, surrounded by bougainvillea and vividly coloured ixora. Yellow, orange, and red, the hues are in harmony with the fabrics of the 103 rooms decorated in colonial style.

The sea view is exceptional, and the small, white sand beach below, with sun beds lined up in a row, is more than inviting. In the distance, you can see the coral reef displaying inimitable shades of blue. You simply will not be able to resist swimming in the turquoise sea, with its colourful fish, or in the large pool by the adjoining restaurant. The service is outstanding and the cuisine refined, with classic and exotic touches. A real treat!

Auberge de la Vieille Tour

https://auberge-vieille-tour.fr/en/

content.title: A journey through the mangroves of Le Grand Cul-de-Sac Marin

introduction.small: Listed as a World Biosphere Reserve by UNESCO, this bay, lined with mangroves, swamp forests, and beaches plays a key ecological role.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A journey through the mangroves of Le Grand Cul-de-Sac Marin

paragraphs.text:
Leave Sainte-Rose by boat for a day trip to this 15,000-hectare marine ecosystem, protected by a large coral reef more than 25 kilometres long. This bay, with its many small islands, offers unique biodiversity in a fragile balance that guarantees the preservation of many animal and plant species.

Accompanied by a guide, you will discover the mangrove and its essential role, including being a 'surrogate mother'. It is a veritable nursery for wildlife, rich in sedentary and migratory sea birds as well as many species of fish, turtles, shellfish, crustaceans, and reptiles. Your boat will then sail to the îlet aux Oiseaux, a place protected from humans and planted with mangroves. Next you will head to îlet Caret for a picnic stop on this little piece of paradise, barely 250m long and 20m wide. The sensation of being on a desert island like Robinson Crusoe is more than just a feeling, as you are surrounded by an empty white sand beach, a few palm trees, and a Caribbean-blue lagoon filled with colourful fish.

And if you come back in a few years, you may be lucky enough to see some manatees, as their reintroduction is now under way.

content.title: Sleeping on Les Saintes at Lô Bleu

introduction.small: On the archipelago of Les Saintes, the Lô Bleu hotel welcomes you to a Creole house on the white sand beach. Its 11 rooms are brightly decorated by local artists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sleeping on Les Saintes at Lô Bleu

paragraphs.text:
The charm of the islands, an easy-going lifestyle, and Caribbean cheerfulness are the three virtues of this small boutique hotel located a few minutes' walk from the centre of the village of Terre-de-Haut, on Les Saintes. It is a perfect place for a simple, relaxing holiday, without constraint, and direct access to the beach and the lagoon in one of the most beautiful bays in the world.

The sunsets, which are simply gorgeous, are not to be missed and are best enjoyed from the shaded terrace of the hotel while sipping your favourite cocktail. There is no restaurant on site, other than breakfast service, but the choices in the village provide everything you could ask for.

The rooms have an arty atmosphere in the spirit of the islands, each one designed by a different artist: there are flowers by Cathy Regnier, fish by Eric Soulier and landscape frescoes by Philippe Remaury, while Pascal Foy uses 'recovered' paintings to create worlds of whimsy on the walls. In short, the perfect setting for any traveller wishing to drift away to the sweet life of Les Saintes.

content.title: Aqua Lodge: your room on the water

introduction.small: Imagine an 80-sqm floating bungalow, with all the comforts of a hotel room, in the turquoise lagoon of Saint-François. This aquatic dream comes true in these trendy, eco-friendly Aqua Lodges.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aqua Lodge: your room on the water

paragraphs.text:
Here is an original concept that is a real departure from traditional hotel service and boating. Anchored in Saint-François Bay, these waterborne bungalows, inspired by catamarans, have everything you could wish for. They are cleanly designed, comfortable, luxurious, and also environmentally friendly. On board, their 80-sqm surface areas are equipped with two bedrooms, a kitchen-living room, a terrace, and a solarium on the upper deck.

Another surprise awaits you in the living room, where you will find a real-life aquarium beneath your feet visible through a glass floor. On deck, activities abound. At your disposal, you will find a stand-up paddleboard, a kayak, fins, masks, and snorkels to explore the seabed around your Aqua Lodge at your leisure. This total freedom is reflected in the lodges' energy autonomy, with solar panels that heat the water.

Reaching the mainland is simple: take your personal tender, equipped with an electric motor. This is a divine holiday concept in the midst of a turquoise lagoon; an original idea just waiting to be experienced.

Aqua Lodge

content.title: La Savane: local cuisine and exotic flavours

introduction.small: One of the best tables in the Côte-sous-le-Vent. A beautiful location in an African savannah setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Savane: local cuisine and exotic flavours

paragraphs.text:
An intimate atmosphere awaits you on the beach in Deshaies, looking over this exceptional bay. In these magnificent surroundings, La Savane invites you on a delicious culinary journey, in a setting that is equally enticing. Natural materials are in the spotlight, particularly wood, which dresses the floors and walls. The safari-inspired furniture is in the same hues.

At the bar, beware of the gorilla, which serves as a seat. The welcoming atmosphere is thanks to the chef Vincent Potiron, who is always smiling. There are no menus here, but refined and reimagined dishes like the crispy foie gras with mango chutney or the marlin steak with its honey and ginger vinaigrette.

In its quest for quality, the restaurant selects the very best fresh produce from around Guadeloupe. This is used in dishes such as the sublime desserts that reveal the full extent of the chef's pastry talents – he learned his trade in prestigious Parisian establishments including Lenôtre and Dalloyau. Be prepared for a festival of flavours capped off with crème brulée perfumed with lime, a mango emulsion, or pineapple with basil.

La Savane
Boulevard des Poissonniers
97126 Deshaies

+590 (0)5 90 91 39 58

https://www.facebook.com/lasavanedeshaies/

Menu: around 33 EUR

content.title: Deshaies, the pearl of Basse-Terre

introduction.small: Authentic and discreet, Deshaies has retained the charm of the old fishing villages of yesteryear. Creole houses, a botanical garden, and wild beaches are all good reasons to stop here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Deshaies, the pearl of Basse-Terre

paragraphs.text:
On the Côte-sous-le-Vent of Basse-Terre, surrounded by hills and bathed by the Caribbean, the miraculously preserved village of Deshaies is an inviting break.

Take a tour around the town and make a detour through the two streets lined with colourful wooden houses, or take a reflective break in the Botanical Garden. The gardener and nursery creator Michel Gaillard designed it on the former property of the French comedian Coluche, and everywhere you look is simply stunning. Right in the heart of the garden the orchid, cacti and tropical plant collections are home to to parrots, parakeets and flamingos, and will delight visitors of all ages. If the weather is clear, enjoy the view of the sea and the island of Montserrat. While here, you simply must visit the beach of Grande Anse, certainly the most beautiful in Basse-Terre, but also the longest, lined with shady palm trees, fishermen's huts, and colourful boats. It is also a favourite picnic stop. Other beaches, like La Perle, Tillet, Rifflet, or Fort Royal, also add to the reputation of this market town.

Finally, savour the Caribbean atmosphere in one of the town's restaurants, which serve absolutely divine Creole food, and why not a traditional ti'-punch too?

Jardin Botanique de Deshaies
Impasse Villers
97126 Deshaies

+590 (0)5 90 28 43 02

https://www.jardin-botanique.com/en/home/

content.title: Guadeloupe rum: among the best in the world!

introduction.small: A real 'national drink', rum has been produced in Guadeloupe for more than three centuries. Only a few distilleries are still in operation, and here is an overview of the plantations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Guadeloupe rum: among the best in the world!

paragraphs.text:
While here, how can you not take an interest in the production of rum and, especially, the cultivation of sugar cane, two vital aspects of Guadeloupe's history and landscape? Sugar cane now covers one third of the agricultural area of the archipelago and is used exclusively for the production of this historical spirit. Harvesting takes place from February to June and it takes ten kilos of sugar cane to make one litre of rum.

There are two types of production: agricultural rum, the most prestigious, is obtained by fermentation and distillation of sugar cane juice; and industrial or traditional rum, which is derived from the fermentation of molasses. Nearly all the distilleries offer tours of their facilities.

Marie-Galante has three renowned distilleries: Bellevue, the oldest, Bielle and Poisson-Père Labat. The others are in Basse-Terre and Haute-Terre: Bologne in Basse-Terre, Montebello in Petit-Bourg, Reimonenq in Sainte-Rose, Damoiseau in Moule, and Longueteau in Capesterre-Belle Eau. Most of them have the distinction of being family-run businesses.

content.title: La Désirade: a timeless journey

introduction.small: Eight kilometres from Grande-Terre, this charming little island is a peaceful refuge set on turquoise waters, lined with idyllic deserted beaches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Désirade: a timeless journey

paragraphs.text:
Visited by Christopher Columbus in 1493, this island, so 'desired' by sailors after long weeks at sea, was named on the spot. Wild and not very touristy, La Désirade is 11 kilometres long and two kilometres wide. One west-to-east road crosses the villages of Galets, Beausejour, Souffleur, and Baie-Mahault, all located on the south coast of the island, which is lined with remarkable white sandy beaches.

The best of these sandy stretches is undoubtedly that of the Souffleur, which is also the favourite of the whales that come to bask there from January to March. The scenery changes on the north coast, which is still for the most part uninhabited and fairly inaccessible. There, steep cliffs lashed by waves offer an eventful show with indomitable landscapes for savvy hikers. A perfect example is the Pointe Doublé, which looks practically Irish, or the solitary peak of the Grand-Abaque, to the northwest.

Off the coast of La Désirade, the Petite-Terre Nature Reserve awaits apprentice Robinson Crusoes.

La Désirade Tourism Office
Rue Victor Schœlcher
La Capitainerie
97127 La Désirade

+590 (0)5 90 84 61 39

https://www.facebook.com/Office-de-Tourisme-de-la-D%C3%A9sirade-639692992719486/

content.title: Les Saintes: one of the most beautiful bays in the world

introduction.small: South of Guadeloupe, Les Saintes archipelago is an irresistibly beautiful paradise, with turquoise waters, countless species of fish, and colourful houses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Saintes: one of the most beautiful bays in the world

paragraphs.text:
Located 30 minutes by boat from Basse-Terre, Les Saintes are composed of nine small islands, of which only two are inhabited: Terre-de-Haut relies on fishing, and Terre-de-Bas is rooted in agriculture. Undoubtedly the best-known is Terre-de-Haut, with its breathtaking bay, among the most beautiful on our planet: a paradise of 15 square kilometres, it has a charming car-free village lined with multi-coloured wooden houses that are inhabited by fishermen with blue eyes and fair skin, descendants of the small Breton colony that landed there in the 17th century.

An enchanting place for hiking, particularly around Fort Napoleon, or for snorkelling activities to discover exceptional underwater seascapes, the island is full of diverse and varied water activities, including kite surfing, scuba diving, snorkelling and much more! Those seeking relaxation can also enjoy the many island beaches and may have the chance to attend the laying of eggs or the birth of sea turtles on Grande Anse beach: usually at dusk from May to July.

Finally, if you still have some time, take the boat to Terre-de-Bas, smaller and more hidden away, but just as enticing as its big sister.

Terre-de-Haut Tourism Office
18 rue Jean Calot
97137 Terre-de-Haut
Les Saintes

+590 (0)5 90 94 30 61

https://fr-fr.facebook.com/terredehauttourisme

content.title: A charming colonial house in the volcano's shadow

introduction.small: A charming nine-room hotel in the south of Basse-Terre, the Jardin Malanga is a sanctuary of peace where time seems to stand still.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A charming colonial house in the volcano's shadow

paragraphs.text:
Nestled at the foot of the Madeleine volcano in a natural setting, the hotel is a gem where calm and tranquillity reign. The main house is a former colonial residence, built in 1927, dressed in brown wood, with its big veranda and balconies in saltires or St. Andrew's cross, typical of Caribbean architecture. Furnished in colonial style, the house has two bedrooms upstairs and a suite on the ground floor.

The other rooms, hidden in the greenery in the three cottages, are as charming and romantic as you could wish. Each has two bedrooms, one downstairs and one upstairs, with an individual terrace. Listening to the sounds of nature, nestled comfortably in your hammock is a delight, as is admiring the large infinity pool overlooking the ocean and Les Saintes.

Dining options include breakfast served by the pool and, for dinner, the guest table featuring locally sourced products is excellent. A must for a romantic getaway.

Le Jardin Malanga
60 Route de l'Hermitage
97114 Trois-Rivières

+590 (0)5 90 92 67 57

https:///www.jardinmalanga.com/hotel-guadeloupe/?lang=en

Rooms: from 185.30 EUR

content.title: La Toubana Hotel & Spa: the charm of the Caribbean

introduction.small: The La Toubana hotel offers stunning views at the entrance to the charming Sainte-Anne village. The same joy can be found in the 32 bungalows overlooking the ocean, facing Marie-Galante.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Toubana Hotel & Spa: the charm of the Caribbean

paragraphs.text:
Set amidst lush vegetation and lulled by the trade winds, the La Toubana Hotel & Spa's 33 orange-toned bungalows hug the hillside overlooking Marie-Galante, Les Saintes, and La Désirade in an idyllic setting. All rooms and suites are tastefully decorated and modern, with an added Caribbean touch of charm. They each feature a large terrace where you can enjoy the divine view or admire the sunset.

Below, the infinity pool blends into the turquoise-blue waters of the Caribbean Sea. If you prefer the ocean life, the little white sand beach at the foot of the hotel will be your favourite spot.

The hotel has also built three four-bedroom villas at the top of the domain. This new concept, with architecture in harmony with the environment, is perfect for sharing the authentic fishing village character of Sainte-Anne with families or groups of friends.

La Toubana Hotel & Spa
97180 Saint-Anne

+590 (0)5 90 88 25 78 / +590 (0)5 90 88 25 57

http://toubana.com/hotel-ile-guadeloupe/?lang=en

Rooms: from 275 EUR

content.title: Memorial ACTe remembers the slave trade

introduction.small: Opened in May 2015, the Caribbean Centre for Expressions and Memory of the Slave Trade and Slavery, the largest memorial of its kind in the world, is Pointe-à-Pitre's flagship building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Memorial ACTe remembers the slave trade

paragraphs.text:
Visible from the sea, it radiates throughout Guadeloupe and the Caribbean. At once a shrine, museum, art centre, and congress hall, it contributes to the raising of consciousness for better sharing and understanding. The choice of location has symbolic significance, since it is built on the site of the former Darboussier sugar factory, where forced labour was still practiced in the 19th century.

Its bold architecture is based on two buildings connected by a monumental arch of perforated aluminium. Highly symbolic, the facades are covered with black quartz chips, which represent the millions of souls who were victims of the slave trade and slavery.

Inside the museum, the permanent exhibition is structured around six educational areas dedicated to the conquest of the Americas, the introduction of slavery, its abolition, and different contemporary movements. There is also a space for temporary exhibitions and a conference room, as well as multipurpose spaces. On the second floor, between sky and sea, an outdoor 275m walkway connects the ACTe Memorial to the 'Morne Memory', a large garden with panoramic views of the bay.

Mémorial ACTe
Darboussier

97110 Pointe-à-Pitre

+590 (0)5 90 25 16 00

memorial-acte.fr/the-founding-acte-memory-holds-the-future

content.title: Diving under the stars

introduction.small: A night-diving expedition to discover surprising animal and plant species. Thrills are guaranteed with this unique experience!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Diving under the stars

paragraphs.text:
Discover abundant and fascinating underwater life during this night dive in the tropical waters of the Caribbean.

This three-hour exploration off the Islet of Gosier, is organised by the Guadeloupe Aquarium and run by experienced diving instructors in whom you can put your trust. Equipped with flippers, mask and snorkel, you will be guided by instructors across this vast marine garden to discover and observe the nightlife of lobsters, crabs, and fish, as well as many other riches. These wildlife species are often invisible by day, but magically stir at nightfall. This mysterious journey offers a world of incredible sophistication, and a stunning spectacle that will never grow old.

These underwater excursions are open to anyone who can swim and welcome children aged 8 and up. All materials are provided for you on site, but advanced booking is essential.

Seatour - Aquarium de la Guadeloupe
Place Créole
Marina
97190 Le Gosier

+590 (0)5 90 90 92 38 / +590 (0)6 90 57 60 69

http://www.seatour.fr/

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Pointe-a-Pitre
content.introduction:
Guadeloupe enjoys a tropical climate year-round. There are two distinct seasons on the islands: a dry season known as Carême (Lent) from December to April, and a rainy season, called Hivernage (Wintering) from mid-June to November, when there are frequent, intense bouts of rainfall.

The weather remains warm year-round, with an annual average of 27°C (81°F). During the warmest months, the temperature ranges from 25°C to 32°C (77°F to 90°F) on average, while it varies between 23°C and 29°C (73°F and 84°F) on average during the coldest ones. Hurricane season in Guadeloupe runs from May to November. Rainfall can be heavy from August to November. But with record-setting sunshine (nearly 3,000 hours each year) and water temperatures of 28°C (82°F) on average, Guadeloupe is still a dream destination.

airports.title: Guadeloupe Pointe-à-Pitre Le Raizet Airport
airports.description:
The International airport of Guadeloupe Pointe-à-Pitre Le Raizet is located about 7km (4 miles) north of the city of Pointe-à-Pitre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2

Getting from the airport to Pointe-à-Pitre and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via Rue Pompilius Keller: journey takes around 15 16 minutes.
    • There are three parking facilities: P0 (drop-off, first 10 minutes are free), P1 (short-term parking, first 10 minutes are free, then EUR 4 for 1 hour) and P2 (long-term parking, EUR 30 for 24 hours then EUR 5 per extra day)
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available just outside the airport. The fare to Pointe-à-Pitre is about EUR 25 (night fare is EUR 32).
  • By bus
    • The AE1 bus line of the Karu'lis network (https://www.karulis.com) connects the airport to the city centre of Pointe-à-Pitre. EUR 1.20 each way.
  • Services: shops, bars, restaurants, free internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +590 (0)5 90 21 14 72
  • Website: www.guadeloupe.aeroport.fr

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Pointe-a-Pitre
transportation.description: Public transport is not very well developed in Guadeloupe. Renting a car is a good way to get around. Bicycling and walking are also excellent options, in order to fully appreciate the awe-inspiring landscapes of the islands.

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Pointe-a-Pitre
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Guadeloupe each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: May 1 : Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: May 27 : Emancipation Day (local holiday)
events.description: Celebration eagerly awaited by all Guadeloupians and consisting in cultural encounters, exhibitions and remembrance marches, organised in memory of all victims of slavery.

events.title: June 21 : Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are organised across Guadeloupe's streets and parks, in a festive and friendly atmosphere!

events.title: July 14 : Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates both the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Guadeloupe, military parades take place each year on the occasion.

events.title: July 21 : Schoelcher Day (local event)
events.description: Remembrance and celebration of the part played by Victor Schoelcher in the abolition of slavery in Martinique, Guadeloupe and Saint Martin. Each year on this day, parades and other events are held.

events.title: Third weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up sites and monuments such as castles and private collections, many of which are normally closed to the public. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll to admire some architectural treasures!

events.title: November 1 & 2: All Saints Day and All Souls Day (local holiday)
events.description: On these days, cemeteries are lit with candles and families get together to clean gravestones and talk until the sun sets.

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, citizens gather at the war memorial in Pointe-à-Pitre to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Pointe-à-Pitre, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping?
In Guadeloupe like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
